title: How to Make Red Velvet Jello Shots

steps.headline: Slice your lemons and limes in half.
steps.description: You can roll each lemon and lime a few times against a hard surface to get the juices flowing first, if you like. Then use a sharp knife to cut each fruit in half. Use any ratio of lemon and lime juice. If you prefer one over the other, you can just use that particular juice.

steps.headline: Juice the limes and lemons.
steps.description: If you have a juicer, use that to squeeze out as much juice as possible from the halves into a cup or bowl. If you don't have a juicer, you can simply squeeze the fruit over a bowl to get out as much juice as you can.

steps.headline: Simmer the water and sugar for 3 to 5 minutes.
steps.description: Measure out your water and sugar abd place both of them together in a small pot. Simmer the mixture over medium-high heat. Keep simmering until the sugar is completely dissolved. It is not necessary to stir. Times will vary, but sugar should normally dissolve within 3 to 5 minutes.

steps.headline: Add the lemon and lime juice.
steps.description: Once your sugar is dissolved, turn down the heat to medium low. Add your lemon and lime juice. Mix the lemon and lime juice until you have a smooth, even mixture.

steps.headline: Bring the mixture to a boil.
steps.description: If you were making a sour mix for cocktails or another purpose, you would remove it from the heat after adding the lemon and lime juice. However, in this case, you need to boil the sour mixture for your shots. Turn the heat up and leave the mixture on the stove until it comes to a boil.

steps.headline: Measure out 3 ounces of the boiling sour mix for your shots.
steps.description: Remove the mixture from the heat. A shot glass is typically 1.5 ounces, so a quick and easy way of measuring 3 ounces is simply to fill up 2 shot glasses with the mixture. This will be enough for your red velvet jello shot recipe.

steps.headline: Store the remaining sour mix.
steps.description: Place the leftover sour mixture in an airtight container. Keep it stored in the fridge. You can use it later to make cocktails. It should keep for about 2 weeks.

steps.headline: Add your boiling sour mix to your gelatin.
steps.description: In a mixing bowl, add your boiling sour mix and gelatin. Make sure to mix these ingredients right away before the sour mixture stops boiling.

steps.headline: Stir for about 2 minutes.
steps.description: Use a spoon to stir the gelatin and boiling sour mix until the gelatin dissolves. While this normally takes around 2 minutes, it may take a bit longer or shorter depending, on the precise heat of your sour mix.

steps.headline: Add the alcohol to the mixture.
steps.description: Once the gelatin is dissolved, add both alcohols -- the whiskey and the liqueur -- to the sour mix/gelatin mixture. Stir the mixture together until everything is evenly incorporated.

steps.headline: Grease ice cube trays with a nonstick cooking spray.
steps.description: Shake a can of nonstick cooking spray. Apply a light coating to your ice trays, taking care to get into nooks and crannies. A little bit goes a long way, so you won't need to use much cooking spray for this. You can also grease a shallow cooking tray and use that instead of ice cube trays. Later you will simply have to use a greased knife to cut the mixture into shot-sized pieces.

steps.headline: Pour the shots into the ice cube trays.
steps.description: Transfer your gelatin mixture to a container with a spout, like a glass or plastic measuring cup. Fill each compartment of your ice trays to the brim with the gelatin mixture. This recipe makes 16 shots, so use ice trays with enough compartments to accommodate.

steps.headline: Refrigerate the shots overnight.
steps.description: Place the shots in an area of your fridge where they won't be disturbed. Keep them there overnight so the gelatin can set.

steps.headline: Remove the shots to serve.
steps.description: Cover a butter knife with a baking spray. Run it along the sides of each compartment of your ice cube tray and then gently pry out the shots using your knife. You could also dust the shots with a touch of cocoa powder or a sweep spice just before you serve them.

text: Boiling Your Sour Mix Slice your lemons and limes in half. You can roll each lemon and lime a few times against a hard surface to get the juices flowing first, if you like. Then use a sharp knife to cut each fruit in half. Use any ratio of lemon and lime juice. If you prefer one over the other, you can just use that particular juice. Juice the limes and lemons. If you have a juicer, use that to squeeze out as much juice as possible from the halves into a cup or bowl. If you don't have a juicer, you can simply squeeze the fruit over a bowl to get out as much juice as you can. Simmer the water and sugar for 3 to 5 minutes. Measure out your water and sugar abd place both of them together in a small pot. Simmer the mixture over medium-high heat. Keep simmering until the sugar is completely dissolved. It is not necessary to stir. Times will vary, but sugar should normally dissolve within 3 to 5 minutes. Add the lemon and lime juice. Once your sugar is dissolved, turn down the heat to medium low. Add your lemon and lime juice. Mix the lemon and lime juice until you have a smooth, even mixture. Bring the mixture to a boil. If you were making a sour mix for cocktails or another purpose, you would remove it from the heat after adding the lemon and lime juice. However, in this case, you need to boil the sour mixture for your shots. Turn the heat up and leave the mixture on the stove until it comes to a boil. Measure out 3 ounces of the boiling sour mix for your shots. Remove the mixture from the heat. A shot glass is typically 1.5 ounces, so a quick and easy way of measuring 3 ounces is simply to fill up 2 shot glasses with the mixture. This will be enough for your red velvet jello shot recipe. Store the remaining sour mix. Place the leftover sour mixture in an airtight container. Keep it stored in the fridge. You can use it later to make cocktails. It should keep for about 2 weeks. Making Your Shots Add your boiling sour mix to your gelatin. In a mixing bowl, add your boiling sour mix and gelatin. Make sure to mix these ingredients right away before the sour mixture stops boiling. Stir for about 2 minutes. Use a spoon to stir the gelatin and boiling sour mix until the gelatin dissolves. While this normally takes around 2 minutes, it may take a bit longer or shorter depending, on the precise heat of your sour mix. Add the alcohol to the mixture. Once the gelatin is dissolved, add both alcohols -- the whiskey and the liqueur -- to the sour mix/gelatin mixture. Stir the mixture together until everything is evenly incorporated. Setting the Shots Grease ice cube trays with a nonstick cooking spray. Shake a can of nonstick cooking spray. Apply a light coating to your ice trays, taking care to get into nooks and crannies. A little bit goes a long way, so you won't need to use much cooking spray for this. You can also grease a shallow cooking tray and use that instead of ice cube trays. Later you will simply have to use a greased knife to cut the mixture into shot-sized pieces. Pour the shots into the ice cube trays. Transfer your gelatin mixture to a container with a spout, like a glass or plastic measuring cup. Fill each compartment of your ice trays to the brim with the gelatin mixture. This recipe makes 16 shots, so use ice trays with enough compartments to accommodate. Refrigerate the shots overnight. Place the shots in an area of your fridge where they won't be disturbed. Keep them there overnight so the gelatin can set. Remove the shots to serve. Cover a butter knife with a baking spray. Run it along the sides of each compartment of your ice cube tray and then gently pry out the shots using your knife. You could also dust the shots with a touch of cocoa powder or a sweep spice just before you serve them.
